title: The heartbreaking story behind this photo
text:
— Barry Malone (@malonebarry) August 16, 2015 
Greece is struggling to deal with the arrival of about 160,000 migrants — virtually all of them fleeing war and persecution in Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq — who have landed on its shores since January, according to the UN refugee agency. 
The Greek islands close to Turkey have borne the brunt of the influx , with authorities overwhelmed and rights groups criticising miserable conditions facing the migrants, who are often forced to sleep in the open for weeks and queue for days to secure departure papers. 
Mr Etter seemed to verify just how stretched the Greek authorities are with the refugee crisis. On August 16 (before his photo was published) he tweeted that he was “at a beach in Kos this AM. Heard scream for help out of the dark. Informed the coast guard who was reluctant to come”. 
In another tweet he added: “Came after more than one hour, and pulled out two drifting boats.” 
While it is not known if Mr Majid was on one of those boats, it is clear many desperate refugees are risking their lives to escape the horror of their war-torn homes. Syrian refugees arrive at a beach on the Greek island of Kos. Source: Getty Images 
A Greek government-chartered ferry is transporting some 2600 Syrian refugees to the Greek mainland today. The Eleftherios Venizelos left the island of Kos with about 1700 Syrian refugees on board, and picked up another 900 on the islands of Kalymnos, Leros and Lesbos. Two Syrian refugees are clearly relieved to be in Greece, as they swim from their boat. Source: AP 
“The situation is out of control,” Leros mayor Michalis Kolias said in a letter to the government, asking for help in getting hundreds of migrants off the island. 
“The lives of irregular migrants and of the island’s residents and visitors are in danger,” Kolias said, pointing to health risks from overcrowding. Thousands of families are making the journey. Source: AFP Greek riot police are trying to control the refugees by chasing them away from areas of Kos. Source: AP 
Ultimately, these images encapsulate the pain felt by many refugees as they struggle to make a better life for their families. And others, show hope. 
Millions of people around the world have now seen the picture, with the overwhelming response being one of empathy with those that are trying to make a new life. Family members hug each other after successfully arriving at Kos. Source: AP Reaching the relative safety of Greek shores is an overwhelming moment for many refugees. Source: AFP Against the Tide 52:59
